The concept that DNA alone is responsible for all heritable traits between individuals in a population has been so hammered into peoples' brains by science and the media that it's going to be difficult to unhammer it. But that's exactly what needs to be done. And in the process of doing so, the whole theory of evolution will have to be reworked.
 
 Recently much has been said on this forum about nonrandom variation. My contention is that it undermines selection. But let's look at both sides of the issue: According to ToE, traits arise randomly, unoriented to the environment and unbiased to adaptive improvement. If this indeed is the case, it would be fair to assume that each organism in a given population would be subject to selection because each would be blessed with varying abilities, which would ultimately bring about competition to survive. The key here, of course is random variation. Here's Richard Dawkin's take on variation. Please keep in mind that he doesn't even bring up epigenetics in his books, he's still living in fairytale land that mutation is the begetter of all change. Having said that, notice his emphatic denial of any adaptive direction to variation and that selection is the only thing that gives direction to evolution:
 
 "There is a fifth respect in which mutation might have been nonrandom. We can imagine (just) a form of mutation that was systematically biased in the direction of improving the 
 animal's adaptedness to its life. But although we can imagine it, nobody has ever come close to suggesting any means by which this bias could come about. It is only in this fifth respect, the 'mutationist' respect, that the true, real-life Darwinian insists that mutation is 
 random. Mutation is not systematically biased in the direction of adaptive improvement, and no mechanism is known (to put the point mildly) that could guide mutation in directions that are non-random in this fifth sense. Mutation is random with respect to adaptive advantage, although it is non- random in all sorts of other respects. It is selection, and only selection, that directs evolution in directions that are nonrandom with respect to advantage."(Dawkins R., "The Blind Watchmaker," [1986], Penguin: London, 1991, reprint, p.312)
 
 Dawkins, though he is wrong about the nonrandomness of mutation, understands his predicament. He knows -- though many in here do not -- that the only way that a mechanical system of evolution will hold up is if variation is random. Period. No ifs ands or buts.
 
 To stick another fork in this dead bird, according to ToE, evolution is seen in terms of changes in gene frequencies and DNA sequences. But with epigenetics it's not so much changes in genes (or not at all, actually) but simply a change in traits. And that's the kicker. Evolutionists in here like to embrace epigenetics, but what they don't realize is by doing so, they are admitting that evolution is no longer an accumulation of selected genes ----- instead, it's an accumulation of selected traits. Oops.
 
 So with that, it's going to get real hairy....and here's why. Evolutionists, up until now, have made it easy on themselves; they've said genes do funny things for no apparent reason; genes simply mutate, end of story. But now everything gets more complicated because instead of simple, mindless changes in genes, they now have to incorporate everything that goes into creating a new, purposeful, heritable epigenetic trait. This, of course, requires the observance of the animal as a whole, which goes against their religion of reductionism. And along with that, as opposed to just focusing on one particular gene, science now has to look at all the countless, insanely-complex network of interactions that go on in the body. They also have to somehow decipher how the information from the environment gets transmitted to the organism. This begins with a process of thoughts, sensations, beliefs, or other mystical feelings on behalf of the organism, which then somehow get manifested into physical realities. And this ain't science -- because science will never be able to answer such questions; this is philosophy. Is it any wonder epigenetics has been hidden in the closet?
 
 But back to natural selection:
 
 So, I could certainly see, if variation was truly random that selection could theoretically pick from a pool of random variants. Unfortunately for evolutionists, the concept of randomness when it comes to new traits has never actually been proven. In fact, whenever animals experience an environmental shift, they have this bad habit of shifting right along with it, starting with an internal response from each creature who somehow "senses" this change. It's hardly logical to call this random. 
 
 But if each individual of a population experiences the same environmental cue, and each member simultaneously evolves the same traits epigenetically, not only will this speed up evolution exponentially, but it will also give each member the same traits at the same time -- which ultimately gives them the same basic fitness ----- which undermines natural selection, making mortality/breeding success mostly a lottery of circumstance, with a little sexual selection thrown in.

 Maybe it might help clarify my rambles above if I paint a picture of how I suspect most biologists think these days. Suppose that the genotype of a parental organism is represented by a dot on a fitness landscape. Within a circle around that dot, are the positions that could be occupied by progeny genotypes that vary from the parent by some feasible mutation in the DNA sequence.
 
 Now a simplistic view of Darwinian random mutation would suggest that every point within that circle has an equal chance of being occupied by progeny that are exposed to natural selection in the fitness landscape. In this view, progeny should be evenly but randomly dispersed over the entire circle. However, this isn't a necessary condition. Darwinian theory doesn't insist that every spot within that circle should have an equal chance of containing a variant visible to NS. 
 
 Random mutation really means that any piece of DNA has as much of a chance of receiving a sequence mutation as any other. However, constraints such as developmental ones mean that not all of these mutations are ever going to see the light of day in a functional organism visible to NS. So although mutations in themselves can be random, and there is no reason I'm aware of to think they aren't, only a certain proportion of them will result in organisms viable enough to be screened by NS. So the mutations that survive long enough to be observed by an evolutionary biologist could be very non-random.
 
 IOW, the dots in the circle of progeny do not have to be evenly dispersed. They can have a very non-random distribution. However, this distribution would still be subject to the forces of natural selection imposed by the fitness landscape. Progeny genotypes that cropped up on the favourable (uphill towards a local fitness peak) side(s) of the circle would have a better chance of survival than those elsewhere (downhill from the fitness peak).
 
 So even constraints can be accommodated by what is basically a Darwinian theory. In this view, mutations in DNA sequence are random; a few of these are pre-selected by constraints or canalisation; those are then exposed to natural selection. And of course, some kinds of mutations might be more probable owing to structural or other factors than others, or some DNA sequences be more vulnerable to mutations than others. 
 
 What I don't think we are going to see is a full scale rejection of Darwinian evolution. Whatever changes occur, I doubt it will be a truly revolutionary replacement of one theory by a completely different one, just an expansion or modification.

 Repeated darwinist errors-- For example--
 That since organisms are constructed out of 'bits of stuff', they react when acted upon in the same way, i.e.,deterministically,mechanically, exactly as their constituent 'bits of stuff' do, taken separately.
 
 This is the logical fallacy whereby the properties of one or more parts are said to describe the properties of the whole. It is called, "the fallacy of composition". It is the worst problem with materialist/mechanist reductionism, and is repeated by Hanks and other darwinists with reference to genes and other chemicals determining what is a live organism and why it behaves as it does, as above. The wikipedia describes this fallacy thus--
 "A fallacy of composition arises when one infers that something is true of the whole from the fact that it is true of some (or even every) part of the whole. For example: "This fragment of metal cannot be broken with a hammer, therefore the machine of which it is a part cannot be broken with a hammer." This is clearly fallacious, because many machines can be broken into their constituent parts without any of those parts being so breakable."
 
 The fact is that the bits of stuff we call DNA do nothing, in and of themselves, but are purely passive, doing only what an external, volitional, agency makes them do. They are formed into a code according to the dictates on an external agency that teleological writes that code, intending that the information in that code be retrieved during reproduction and used during development of another organism.--
 
 {Nota Benae--darwinists would have us believe that the genetic code was conceived accidentally and is written randomly, unintentionally, by "natural", (by which they always mean 'physically mechanical'), forces. The notion that any code of any kind could ever be conceived of, written, and interpreted by random accident is just too stupidly childish to merit further comment.}
 
 --But once a code is broken, then any other intelligent agency can not only translate that code, but also re-write it, intentionally. That is what genetic engineers are intelligently and volitionally doing with the genetic code--re-shuffling passive bits of DNA to create new reproductive messages, in code, for the dynamic organism to follow. And so long as the organism finds these "re-writes" and "edits" to its advantage, there is no reason why it should object to them or resist them, the way it does random mutations.
 
 Still, it remains to be seen for how many generations a genetically modified organism will continue to passively accept even beneficial human interference in its reproductive system. Homeostasis
 
 In a simple analogy, think of a cell as a box that must be maintained at a constant temperature. It has a source of power, a thermostat, a thermometer, and heating or refrigerating devices. The thermostat corresponds to the control "master" gene; the heaters and frigistors are functional genes whose controlled activities change the temperature of the box; and the thermometer is the way the master gene senses the state of the environment, so it can transduce that information into signals that switch heaters and frigistors on or off.
 
 So long as energy is available, and worn parts can be replaced, the box will maintain an even temperature forever. 
 
 Now think in biochemical terms with concentrations of interacting molecules in place of heat, and raise the complexity (number of interdependent systems) to a vast power, and you have a real cell maintaining its environment. That is homeostasis.
 
 In biochemistry, it's the concentrations and locations of various biomolecules of all sort of shapes, sizes and complexities that is controlled by the homeostatic system.

 And who, or what, 'regulates' the "hox genes"?

 
 The epigenetic environment laid down in the egg by the mother. There are gradients of RNA and protein established in the egg during its synthesis by maternal cells that secrete the constituents of the egg, and which affect the way control genes such as Hox are initially expressed in various parts of the embryo. http://ourworld.compuserve.com/homepages/dp5/lipton.htm
 
 Darwinism and epigenetics
 
 Lipton argues that genes cannot control life because they cannot turn themselves on or off. That is done by signals from the cellular environment. Epigenetics, the study of the molecular mechanisms by which the environment controls gene activity, is today one of the most active areas of scientific research. Environmental influences, including nutrition, stress, and emotions, can modify genes, without changing their basic blueprint, and these modifications can be passed on to future generations. DNA makes up only half the content of chromosomes; the other half consists of regulatory proteins, which are turning out to play as crucial a role in heredity as DNA. Studies of protein synthesis reveal that epigenetic factors can create 2000 or more variations of proteins from the same gene blueprint.
 
 Biologists' central dogma (first formulated by Francis Crick) posits the 'primacy of DNA', involving a one-way flow of information from DNA to RNA to proteins. Lipton, on the other hand, argues for the 'primacy of the environment'. Regulatory genes direct the activity of protein-encoding genes, but environmental signals control how regulatory proteins bind to DNA. The flow of information is therefore: environmental signal - regulatory protein - DNA - RNA - protein. Information can also flow in the reverse direction, but subject to tight restrictions: RNA can rewrite DNA, protein antibodies can change DNA, and changes in DNA influence the binding of regulatory proteins.
 
 Evidence for the role of epigenetic mechanisms has become so compelling that some scientists have started speaking favourably again of Jean-Baptiste de Lamarck (1744-1829), the much-scorned evolutionist who believed that traits acquired as result of environmental influence could sometimes be passed on to offspring. The genome is certainly turning out to be far more fluid and responsive to the environment than previously supposed. It is clear that DNA does not control biology, and that information can be transmitted to descendants in ways other than through the base sequence of DNA.
 
 Whereas traditional darwinism sees evolution as essentially random, purposeless, and violently competitive, Lamarck suggested that evolution was based on cooperative interaction among organisms and their environment. In Darwin's Blind Spot (2002), Frank Ryan chronicles a number of striking examples of cooperation among organisms. For instance, there is a yellow shrimp that gathers food while its partner gobi fish protects it from predators. There is also a species of hermit crab that carries a pink anemone on top of its shell. Fish and octopuses like to feed on hermit crabs, but when they approach this species, the anemone shoots out its brilliantly coloured tentacles, with their microscopic batteries of poisoned darts, and stings the potential predator. In return, the anemone eats the crab's leftover food.
 
 We now know that genes are transferred between members of the same species and of different species. This highlights the dangers of genetic engineering. Tinkering with the genes of a tomato, for example, could alter the entire biosphere in unforeseen ways. One study has shown that when humans digest genetically modified foods, the artificially created genes transfer into and alter the beneficial bacteria in the intestine. Similarly, gene transfer among genetically engineered agricultural crops and surrounding native species has given rise to highly resistant superweeds. As Lipton says, scientists are messing around with our genes and environment without understanding how interconnected everything is.
 
 Cells, brains, membranes
 
 Although cells appear to be anatomically simple, they display incredible complexity and power, and employ technologies that scientists have barely begun to understand. Like humans, single cells analyze thousands of stimuli from the microenvironment they inhabit, and select appropriate behavioural responses to ensure their survival. They are even capable of altering their own genes.
 
 Lipton rejects the orthodox idea that the nucleus is the cell's brain. If their nuclei and genes are removed, cells can survive for up to two months or more. They continue to exhibit complex, coordinated, life-sustaining behaviours, but eventually die - not because they have lost their brain but because they have lost their reproductive capabilities and are unable to replace failed proteins or replicate themselves. In other words, the nucleus is the cell's gonad. Lipton comments:
 
 Confusing the gonad with the brain is an understandable error because science has always been and still is a patriarchal endeavor. Males have often been accused of thinking with their gonads, so it's not entirely surprising that science has inadvertently confused the nucleus with the cell's brain! (p. 66)
 
 Lipton proposes that the true brain controlling cellular life is the membrane - the 'magical mem-brain', as he calls it. The membrane is a semi-permeable, three-layered skin, only seven millionths of a millimetre thick, which holds the contents of a cell together. But behind its apparent simplicity lies great functional complexity. For instance, prokaryotes, which include bacteria and other microbes, consist of a cell membrane enveloping a droplet of cytoplasm, yet they display 'intelligence'. They can sense the presence of food and propel themselves towards it, and they can recognize toxins and predators and take evasive action.
 
 Instead of the cell's operations being controlled by DNA blueprints stored in the nucleus, as conventional biology would have us believe, Lipton proposes that this is done by integral membrane proteins (IMPs) - which include receptor (awareness) and effector (action) proteins. The membrane's effector proteins, operating in response to molecular and radiant-energy signals which its receptors pick up from the environment, control the 'reading' of genes so that worn-out proteins can be replaced or new proteins created.
 
 The cell's operations are therefore primarily moulded by its interaction with the environment, not by its genetic code. Genes cannot preprogram a cell or an organism's life, because cell survival depends on the ability to dynamically adjust to an ever-changing environment. In Lipton's view, the membrane's function of interacting 'intelligently' with the environment to produce behaviour makes it the true brain of the cell; if the membrane is destroyed, the cell dies. In multicellular organisms key functions of the membrane are taken over by specialized tissues and organs - nervous system, lungs, muscles, etc.

 The biology and life cycle of cells and organisms certainly isn't random. No biologist has ever claimed that. DNA sequence mutation -- and recall that to a biologist, a mutation just means any change in a DNA sequence in progeny compared to the parent, and can be as small and simple as a single base change or as large and complex as a chromosomal rearrangement or duplication -- remains the ultimate source of variation and hence diversity. There is as yet no reason to believe that mutations are in any way directed to correspond to some "best" solution in any given environment. Hence the conclusion that mutation is random, with direction provided by a combination of internal structural constrains and external natural selection, which just weeds out the variants which are least effective at reproduction.

It's still a matter of determining which genomes survive into the next generation, and if genes that have "learned" how to cooperate are better survivors than those that compete too aggressively, then Darwinian theory predicts they should increase their frequency in the population.

Chemist you are obviously informed to some degree but you are missing one of the main cruxes of your theory. Darwinism entails a separation of the organism from its environment. This is the basic premise which lead to the so-called Weismann's barrier -- the concept that the organism is closed off to life's experiences, and the only thing of consequence is what genes the organism happens to have.
 
 On the otherhand we have Lamarck's theory, which is a theory of transformation arising from within the organism and arising in response to its life experiences and ecological environment. Lamarck envisioned each organism as an active participant in life who was open to the environment and the process of change was not brought about by an outside force (natural selection) but from within, an internalized transformation.
 
 What you are attempting to do is mesh these together into one. You are attempting to cling to your natural selection while admitting that each individual is adaptive to its surroundings. You are admitting that animals evolve by way of epigenetics (transformation from within) yet holding on to ToE. It simply doesn't work. The two theories are diametrically opposed and they both cannot and do not exist at the same time. It's either one or the other. This is why anything that even hinted of lamarckism has been laughed at, scoffed at and ignored for the past century ---- smart biologists understand the reality of lamarckism; they know the consequences of lamarck getting his foot in the door ---- he blows ToE out of the water with that foot.
 
 Ultimately it comes down to one of two things: either Darwinism, which asserts that there's a constant genetic blueprint or program for making an animal -- a program which is either accepted or rejected by selection .... OR the alternative theory which states that organisms can adapt themselves during development to match their surroundings.
 
 You can't have both.

 Well, chemist has addressed your comments, but let me add a footnote.
 
 First of all, biologists have long known that Darwinian selection is not the only mechanism responsible for evolution. Second, horizontal gene transfer is still part of a selective process, in that organisms transformed by the genetic influx must then be tested against the environment -- this is just an additional way of acquiring novel genetic information, and is not something contrary to Darwinian theory. Third, Darwinian selection is not based on "a platform of randomness", except in the apparent lack of significant directionality in the direction of variation, whether the variation arises by mutation of an indigenous genome or by the invasion of genes from an different genome. Natural selection provides a strong, non-random element to Darwinian theory.
 
 What I'm objecting to in your attacks on Darwinian thinking is not any claim that it can't explain everything about evolution -- that's a given long accepted by biologists since Darwin. It's that new discoveries are making Darwinian theory obsolete. They aren't. There is nothing incompatible between new ways of creating novel genetic information and the selection process through which its utility is tested. Neither is there anything incompatible between selection of genomes in the generation of new species, and the phenotypic adaptability of individual organisms. Such adaptability can also in principle evolve in Darwinian ways. Neither is there anything incompatible between selection mechanisms and the discovery of how a limited set of genes can control development.
 
 You are seeing problems and incompatibilities where none really exist.

Oh, and to concur with chemist, Darwinian selection doesn't require that mutations be totally random in the sense of truly stochastic, it's just that there is thus far no reason to suppose there is any mechanism to direct DNA mutations selectively to favour those which could take advantage of particularities of the environment. For example, if a climate would favour animals who could grow woollier coats in winter than in summer, there is no reason to suppose that a species has the capacity to concentrate its mutations in that direction rather than in others. No such goal-orientated mutational mechanisms have been found, though they have been proposed but not confirmed.
 
 The apparent non-directional nature of mutations, however, doesn't mean that any and all mutations are equally likely. Some kinds may be more common than others, some bits of DNA may be more likely to mutate than others. Further, many, perhaps most mutations will never be exposed to natural selection either because they are invisible to it, resulting in a non-Darwinian evolutionary mechanism called genetic drift, or because structural or developmental constraints prevent the formation of a viable organism to begin with. But even if all conceivable variants aren't equally likely or possible, that doesn't mean that once they appear, they aren't subject to selection by the environment.
 
 Lastly, there is no known mechanism that can account for Lamarckian-type evolution. There have been many experiments by biological hopefuls such as Kammerer with his toads, but never has an acquired characteristic been found to be heritably transmitted. There is simply no known way of faithfully copying changes in a somatic cell's genome to the germ cells, unless they undergo similar DNA mutations or epigenetic alterations through a similar chemical agent, which is unlikely if not impossible. It is true that some epigenetic modifications can survive inter-generational transfer for a few generations because they are made simultaneously to somatic and germ cells, but so far as I know, none are known to survive indefinitely, and they seem be exceptions rather than the rule.
 
 In any case, even if epigenetic transfer of information to new generations is a significant mechanism in evolution, it's still not going to displace Darwinian selection, because that selection process is not wedded to any particular way of transmitting information, whether it is genetic or epigenetic. Even if a stable new species could arise purely by epigenetic modifications -- and this is an interesting question, but there is as yet no evidence that a single genome can encode two separate species -- it would still be subject to natural selection. If evidence for epigenetic speciation is discovered, it would be an additional mechanism within the overarching Darwinian theory, and not a replacement for it

No better way to put the rabble back in their place is there.
 
 From Wikipedia Biological Fitness:
 
 "
Measures of fitness
 
 "There are two commonly used measures of fitness; absolute fitness and relative fitness.
 
 "Absolute fitness (wabs) of a genotype is defined as the ratio between the number of individuals with that genotype after selection to those before selection. It is calculated for a single generation and may be calculated from absolute numbers or from frequencies. When the fitness is larger than 1.0, the genotype increases in frequency; a ratio smaller than 1.0 indicates a decrease in frequency.
 
 w(abs) = N(after)/N(before)
 
 "Absolute fitness for a genotype can also be calculated as the product of the proportion survival times the average fecundity.
 
 "Relative fitness is quantified as the average number of surviving progeny of a particular genotype compared with average number of surviving progeny of competing genotypes after a single generation, i.e. one genotype is normalized at w = 1 and the fitnesses of other genotypes are measured with respect to that genotype. Relative fitness can therefore take any nonnegative value, including 0.
 
 "While researchers can usually measure relative fitness, absolute fitness is more difficult. It is often difficult to determine how many individuals of a genotype there were immediately after reproduction.
 
 "The two concepts are related, and both of them are equivalent when they are divided by the mean fitness, which is weighted by genotype frequencies.
 
 w(abs)/w-(abs) = w(rel)/w-(rel)
 
 "This leads to the well known Fisher's fundamental theorem of natural selection. Fisher's teorem states that: "The rate of increase in the mean fitness of any organism at any time ascribable to natural selection acting through changes in gene frequencies is exactly equal to its genic variance in fitness at that time". This may be somewhat dubious because selection takes place on the individual level, ruling the enrichment of genes (Mayr 2001). In addition, according to Maynard Smith, a population may reach a state of selective equilibrium, in which case the increase of mean fitness is equal to zero, but not ncessarily the variance in fitness.
 
 "Because fitness is a coefficient, and a variable may be multiplied by it several times, biologists may work with "log fitness" (particularly so before the advent of computers). By taking the logarithm of fitness each term may be added rather than multiplied. A fitness landscape, first conceptualized by Sewall Wright, is a way of visualising fitness in terms of a three-dimensional surface on which peaks correspond to local fitness maxima; it is often said that natural selection always progresses uphill but can only do so locally. This can result in suboptimal local maxima becoming stable, because natural selection cannot return to the less-fit "valleys" of the landscape on the way to reach higher peaks.
 
 "The related concept of genetic load measures the overall fitness of a population of individuals of many genotypes whose fitnesses vary, relative to a hypothetical population in which the most fit genotype has become fixed.
 
 "As another example we may mention the definition of fitness given by Maynard Smith in the following way: "Fitness is a property, not of an individual, but of a class of individuals - for example homozygous for allele A at a particular locus. Thus the phrase 'expected number of offspring' means the average number, not the number produced by some one individual. If the first human infant with a gene for levitation were struck by lightning in its pram, this would not prove the new genotype to have low fitness, but only that the particular child was unlucky." This measure is certainly useful in breeding programs, but hardly as a basis of a model of an evolution selecting individuals, because evolution would hardly know if the individual may be selected or not.
 
 "Yet another possible measure has been formulated by Hartl,1981: "The fitness of the individual - having an array x of phenotypes - is the probability, s(x), that the individual will be included among the group selected as parents of the next generation." Then, the mean fitness may be determined as a mean over the set of individuals in a large population.
 
 P(m)= int s(x)*N(m-x)dx
 
 "where N is the p. d. f. of phenotypes in the population, and m is its centre of gravity. This measure is a suitable basis of a model of an evolution selecting individuals. It may in principle take even the stroke of the lightning into consideration. In the case N is a Gaussian it is fairly easily proved that the average information (information entropy, disorder, diversity) of a large population may be maximized by Gaussian adaptation - keeping the mean fitness constant - in accordance with recapitulation, the central limit theorem, the Hardy-Weinberg law and the second law of thermodynamics. This is in contrast to Fisher's fundamental theorem of natural selection.

 http://www.amazon.com/Biological-Emergences-Evolution-Experiment-Theoretical/dp/0262182572/ref=pd_bbs_sr_1/002-0940018-9689629?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1180739894&sr=8-1
 
 
 Natural selection is commonly interpreted as the fundamental mechanism of evolution. Questions about how selection theory can claim to be the all-sufficient explanation of evolution often go unanswered by today's neo-Darwinists, perhaps for fear that any criticism of the evolutionary paradigm will encourage creationists and proponents of intelligent design.
 
 In Biological Emergences, Robert Reid argues that natural selection is not the cause of evolution. He writes that the causes of variations, which he refers to as natural experiments, are independent of natural selection; indeed, he suggests, natural selection may get in the way of evolution. Reid proposes an alternative theory to explain how emergent novelties are generated and under what conditions they can overcome the resistance of natural selection. He suggests that what causes innovative variation causes evolution, and that these phenomena are environmental as well as organismal.
 
 After an extended critique of selectionism, Reid constructs an emergence theory of evolution, first examining the evidence in three causal arenas of emergent evolution: symbiosis/association, evolutionary physiology/behavior, and developmental evolution. Based on this evidence of causation, he proposes some working hypotheses, examining mechanisms and processes common to all three arenas, and arrives at a theoretical framework that accounts for generative mechanisms and emergent qualities. Without selectionism, Reid argues, evolutionary innovation can more easily be integrated into a general thesis. Finally, Reid proposes a biological synthesis of rapid emergent evolutionary phases and the prolonged, dynamically stable, non-evolutionary phases imposed by natural selection. 
 
 Your theory is dead.

Foe example a surface protein in virus (or a cell) is tightly tied to a gene sequence. But the height of a person or that persons risk for cancer is tied to the functioning of perhaps hundereds of individual genes rather than only one. Even eye color is polygenic. Polydactly is a complex trait involving multiple regulatory genes and their specific timing of expression during development. Big deal as they say, we have known all this for many decades now.
 
 We have also known for many decades that the environment can induce heritable changes tis not only epigenetics where this is known and has been known. Consider the mutation experiments done in the 1930s with X-rays and fruit flies. Classic work on the mutational effects of ionizing radiation. Many chemical mutagens are also known including alkylating agents and oxidants. Nothing new there.
 
 And give the above its clear that the environment does cause genetic variability via mutations and such. To this we can now add epigenetic effects due to alkylation and acylation. Whoope do as they say.
 
 And finally SOME acquired traits can be inherited if they are acquired in particular ways - namely by modifying the genes or their control systems in a permanent way. But of course that does not validate the concept that most acquired traits (which alter only somatic cells not in the reproductive line, or genes which are not in the germ line) are NOT hertiable.
 
 None of this has any impact on the therory of evolution since any source of heritable variability is grist for the evolutionary mill. Indeed one need not postulate specific mechanisms of variability so long as the variations are subject to being inherited. After all Darwin developed the original theory with little or no reference to mechanisms of heritability. Indeed his postulated approch to inheritance was incorrect - but that does not affect the evolutionary process at its core.
 
 In other words you will not achieve a falsification of evolution by introducting a new process of heritable variability! I realize you are incapable of realizing this, but that just indicates that you do not understnd your subject matter.
